title: Critical hospital burden: Healthcare-Associated Infections in Germany
text:
Everybody goes to hospital to receive a cure. What if you went there for treatment but ended up with another infection. This is not a rare occurrence since 1 of every 25 patients in Germany were affected. These healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) are a silent crisis that strikes tens of thousands of people every year. In 2011, HAIs resulted in approximately 487,000 cases and claimed over 16,000 lives (Zacher, 2019). To be exact, the burden of HAIs causes more death than from influenza, Salmonella, Hepatitis B, and Measles combined. Despite Germany’s superb hospitals, the highest number of hospital beds and hospitalization rates exposed Germany to risk.
What’s even more shocking? Research found that many of these infections can be prevented with basic changes in hygiene and hospital procedures.
Understanding where these infections occur and which types are most dangerous is crucial for developing effective prevention strategies.

title: Critical hospital burden: Healthcare-Associated Infections in Germany
text:
The Data

Where the data come from?
This analysis uses data from 2011 European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) Point Prevalence Survey with BHAI method
We examined two datasets for Germany:

Representative sample: 46 hospitals with 9,626 patients
Convenience sample: 132 hospitals with 41,539 patients



What was tracked?
BIG 5 types of HAIs

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)
Surgical site infections (SSI)
Bloodstream infections (BSI)
Urinary tract infections (UTI)
Clostridioides difficile (CDI)



What was measured?

Total number of cases
Deaths linked to infection
Years lost to disability or life (YLDs, YLLs, and summed up as DALYs)

As shown in Table 1, healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) remain a major health concern in Germany. In 2011, there were 478,222 cases resulting in 16,245 deaths and 248,920 DALYs. Urinary tract infections were the most common HAI with 214,150 cases, accounting for 45% of all infections. Pneumonia followed with 106,586 cases, while bloodstream infections were relatively uncommon with 26,976 cases. But these only show the number of occurrence not the critical severity.
